nodes.text: were first introduced to Go with the release of
. Go 1.18 was release in March of 2022, during the writing of this
. We, like the Go team, have tried our best to present the current idioms and thoughts on the how, what, when, where, and why questions about generics in Go.

Generic programming is a programming paradigm that allows us to stub out the implementation of a function with a type that will be provided later. This has benefits for both writing, and using, generic functions. With generics we can write functions that can work with multiple types directly, without having to write the same function multiple times, once for each type. When using generic functions, we can continue use our types as concrete types, instead of interface representations.

Interfaces in Go are a powerful concept that allows developers to create flexible and reusable code. Interfaces allow us to define a set of methods that describe the behavior of a type. Any type that implements those methods, and behaviors, is considered to implement that interface.
We have already discussed the benefits and drawbacks of interfaces earlier in this
so we don't have to re-iterate the benefits of interfaces, but let's discuss some problems with interfaces. For example, consider the function defined in
, and the problem of how to write a function that will return the keys for a given map.

nodes.tag: <cmd exec="go doc -cmd -u -src -short Keys" hide-cmd="" language="go" src="src/keys/any" sym="Keys">

nodes.text: A function that returns the keys of a map.

Go is a statically typed language and so we have to specify the type of the map that we want to get the keys from. A map needs to have both its key and value types specified. We also need to specify the type of slice this function will be returning. In order for this function to support all map types we need to use the
, or empty interface, type which will match any type.
While this means we can write a function that we return a list of keys from a map, it also means that this function is difficult to use. Consider a test,
, that tries use a map that isn't of type
. This code fails to compile because the type of map in the test is not compatible with the type of map required by the function.

nodes.name: example

$ go test -v

FAIL	demo [build failed]

# demo [demo.test]
./keys_test.go:20:14: cannot use m (variable of type map[int]string) as map[any]any value in argument to Keys
./keys_test.go:24:10: invalid operation: act[i] < act[j] (operator < not defined on interface)

nodes.text: Compilation error caused by a type mismatch.

is an attempt to solve this problem. First, we need to create a new, interstitial map of the correct type, and copy all of the keys from the original map into the new map. The same is true of trying to handle the results. We need to loop through the returned slice of keys, asserts the keys are of the correct type, and then copy those values into a new slice of the correct type.

nodes.text: Copying maps to satisfy a type constraint.
fixes the tests, it is a very cumbersome way to work with a function such as this. Generics, were designed to help solve exactly this sort of problem.

Generics in Go introduced a new concept to the language, called Type Constraints. Type Constraints allow us to specify that a type fits within a certain set of constraints. This is useful when we want to write a function that can work with multiple types, but we want to be able to specify that the function can only work with a specific type.
For example, so far have been using an
for the key type in a map, and
for the value type. This is fine, but we can use generics to make this more flexible. We may want to use an
Generics allows us to specify those types as constraints when defining a function or a type. Constraints are added with
after the name of the function or type, but before any parameters.
lays out the anatomy of a generic function.

When calling a generic function, or creating a new value of a generic type, the Go compiler needs to know which types are being provided for the generic parameters. So far, we have been letting the Go compiler infer the types of the generic parameters based on the types of the values passed in. In

variable is called, the compiler is unable to infer the types of the generic parameters. The result is a compilation error.

nodes.text: When generics were released in Go 1.18, the Go team, decided to be cautious and not update the standard library immediately to use them. They wanted to see how generics were being used before deciding to update the standard library. As a result of this, the Go team have create a series of packages in the
namespace to experiment with generics. One of these packages is the
package defines a set of constraints for all of the numerical, and comparable types in the language.

nodes.tag: <cmd data-go-version="go1.22.0" doc="golang.org/x/exp/constraints" exec="go doc golang.org/x/exp/constraints" src="src/constraints/pkg">

nodes.text: . This constraint requires that the type be any of the signed integer types,
defined in the Go language, such
, and any types based on those types.

nodes.stdout:
package constraints // import "golang.org/x/exp/constraints"

type Signed interface {
	~int | ~int8 | ~int16 | ~int32 | ~int64
}
    Signed is a constraint that permits any signed integer type. If future
    releases of Go add new predeclared signed integer types, this constraint
    will be modified to include them.

result.stdout:
package constraints // import "golang.org/x/exp/constraints"

type Signed interface {
	~int | ~int8 | ~int16 | ~int32 | ~int64
}
    Signed is a constraint that permits any signed integer type. If future
    releases of Go add new predeclared signed integer types, this constraint
    will be modified to include them.

nodes.tag: <cmd data-go-version="go1.22.0" doc="golang.org/x/exp/constraints.Signed" exec="go doc golang.org/x/exp/constraints.Signed" src="src/constraints/pkg">

nodes.text: , requires the type to be based on
integer type, signed or unsigned, such as

nodes.stdout:
package constraints // import "golang.org/x/exp/constraints"

type Integer interface {
	Signed | Unsigned
}
    Integer is a constraint that permits any integer type. If future releases
    of Go add new predeclared integer types, this constraint will be modified to
    include them.

result.stdout:
package constraints // import "golang.org/x/exp/constraints"

type Integer interface {
	Signed | Unsigned
}
    Integer is a constraint that permits any integer type. If future releases
    of Go add new predeclared integer types, this constraint will be modified to
    include them.

nodes.text: One of the most useful constraints defined in the
. This constraint list all of the comparable types in the language, and any types based on those types. The
constraint covers all numerical types and strings.

nodes.stdout:
package constraints // import "golang.org/x/exp/constraints"

type Ordered interface {
	Integer | Float | ~string
}
    Ordered is a constraint that permits any ordered type: any type that
    supports the operators < <= >= >. If future releases of Go add new ordered
    types, this constraint will be modified to include them.

result.stdout:
package constraints // import "golang.org/x/exp/constraints"

type Ordered interface {
	Integer | Float | ~string
}
    Ordered is a constraint that permits any ordered type: any type that
    supports the operators < <= >= >. If future releases of Go add new ordered
    types, this constraint will be modified to include them.

In Go type assertions, such as those in
, against concrete types is not allowed. This is no reason to assert if
or another types implements the interface, because the compiler already if it can be done.

nodes.text: Testing the a type with constraints.

we covered the basics of generics in Go. We learned how to define constraints, how to use constraints on types, and how to use constraints on methods. Generics is still new to Go, but it is a powerful tool that can be used to make your code more expressive and maintainable.

parser.contents: # Generics [Generics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generic_programming) were first introduced to Go with the release of [Go 1.18](https://go.dev/blog/intro-generics). Go 1.18 was release in March of 2022, during the writing of this . We, like the Go team, have tried our best to present the current idioms and thoughts on the how, what, when, where, and why questions about generics in Go. ## What are Generics? Generic programming is a programming paradigm that allows us to stub out the implementation of a function with a type that will be provided later. This has benefits for both writing, and using, generic functions. With generics we can write functions that can work with multiple types directly, without having to write the same function multiple times, once for each type. When using generic functions, we can continue use our types as concrete types, instead of interface representations. ## The Problem with Interfaces Interfaces in Go are a powerful concept that allows developers to create flexible and reusable code. Interfaces allow us to define a set of methods that describe the behavior of a type. Any type that implements those methods, and behaviors, is considered to implement that interface. We have already discussed the benefits and drawbacks of interfaces earlier in this so we don't have to re-iterate the benefits of interfaces, but let's discuss some problems with interfaces. For example, consider the function defined in , and the problem of how to write a function that will return the keys for a given map. Go is a statically typed language and so we have to specify the type of the map that we want to get the keys from. A map needs to have both its key and value types specified. We also need to specify the type of slice this function will be returning. In order for this function to support all map types we need to use the `any`, or empty interface, type which will match any type. While this means we can write a function that we return a list of keys from a map, it also means that this function is difficult to use. Consider a test, , that tries use a map that isn't of type `map[any]any`. This code fails to compile because the type of map in the test is not compatible with the type of map required by the function. In is an attempt to solve this problem. First, we need to create a new, interstitial map of the correct type, and copy all of the keys from the original map into the new map. The same is true of trying to handle the results. We need to loop through the returned slice of keys, asserts the keys are of the correct type, and then copy those values into a new slice of the correct type. While fixes the tests, it is a very cumbersome way to work with a function such as this. Generics, were designed to help solve exactly this sort of problem. ## Type Constraints Generics in Go introduced a new concept to the language, called Type Constraints. Type Constraints allow us to specify that a type fits within a certain set of constraints. This is useful when we want to write a function that can work with multiple types, but we want to be able to specify that the function can only work with a specific type. For example, so far have been using an `int` for the key type in a map, and `string` for the value type. This is fine, but we can use generics to make this more flexible. We may want to use an `int32` or a `float64` for the key type, and `any` value for the value type. Generics allows us to specify those types as constraints when defining a function or a type. Constraints are added with `[]` after the name of the function or type, but before any parameters. lays out the anatomy of a generic function. For example, in , we define a `Slicer` function that defines a constraint, type `T`, which can be of `any` type. That new `T` type can then be used in the function signature. In , the `Slicer` function will return a slice of `T` values. When calling the `Slicer` function, as seen in we can pass any type, and it returns a slice of that same type back. In our tests we passed a `string` type to the `Slicer` function. At compile time, sees that we are calling the `Slicer` function with a `string` type and then inserts a function with the appropriate typed signature. For example, by passing a `string` type to the `Slicer` function, the compiler generates a function that looks like . ## Multiple Generic Types With an understanding of the basics of generics, let's revisit the `Keys` function in fixed.keys.dey, and update it to support generics. A map has both a key and a value type. We can use generics to specify which types are allowed to be used for both. In generic.start.def, we can specify that the key type, `K`, must of a type `int`, but the value type, `V`, can be of any type. With the changes in generic.start.def we can pass a map of key type `int` and a value type of `string` to the `Keys` function and it will return a slice of `int` values. As generic.start.test shows, This however, doesn't work if we want to use a map key of type `string` or `float64`. To do this we will need to specify a bigger set of constraints for the key type. ## Instantiating Generic Functions When calling a generic function, or creating a new value of a generic type, the Go compiler needs to know which types are being provided for the generic parameters. So far, we have been letting the Go compiler infer the types of the generic parameters based on the types of the values passed in. In instantiation.broken, a variable, `fn`, is being declared and initialized with the `Keys` function from generic.start.def. When the `fn` variable is called, the compiler is unable to infer the types of the generic parameters. The result is a compilation error. In these situations we need to provide the compiler with the types of the generic parameters. In instantiation.fixed The types, `int` and `string`, are being provided when grabbing a reference to the `Keys` function for the variable `fn`. ## Defining Constraints So far we have been using pretty simple types, such as `int` and `any` for the key and value types. But what if we wanted to use more types than just these? To specify which types can be used for a generic parameter, we can use constraints. Constraints are defined in a similar way to interfaces, but instead of specifying a set of methods, we specify a set of types. As a start we can define a constraint, mapkey.doc that requires the type to be an `int`. With the `MapKey` constraint defined in mapkey.doc, we can update the `Keys` function to use it instead of `int` in defining.def ## Multiple Type Constraints Currently, the `MapKey` constraint only allows an `int` to be used for the key. In floatswe to try and use the `Keys` function with a map using a key type of `float64`. The result is a compilation error. When defining constraints we can use the `|` operator to create an intersection of constraints. For example, in or.doc we define a constraint that requires the key type to be either `int` or `float64`. With the change to the `MapKey` constraint in or.doc, we can use the `Keys` function with a map using a key type of `float64`. The tests in or.test now pass. ## Underlying Type Constraints In Go, we are allowed to create new types based on other types. For example, we can create a new type, `MyInt`, that is based on the `int` type. However, when we try to use the `Keys` function with a map using a key type of `MyInt` we will get a compile error. The reason for the compilation in underlying.broken, is that the type `MyInt`, while based on `int`, does not satisfy the `MapKey` constraint because it is **not** an `int` itself. When writing constraints we, usually, are interested in the underlying type, not the type that is wrapped by the type. To express this in when defining a constraint we can use the `~` operator. By updating the constraint to use the `~` operator, the `Keys` function will accept any type based on `int`. Because `MyInt` is based on `int`, we can now use the `Keys` function with a map using a key type of `MyInt`. ## The Constraints Package When generics were released in Go 1.18, the Go team, decided to be cautious and not update the standard library immediately to use them. They wanted to see how generics were being used before deciding to update the standard library. As a result of this, the Go team have create a series of packages in the golang.org/x/exp namespace to experiment with generics. One of these packages is the golang.org/x/exp/constraints package, constraints.doc. The golang.org/x/exp/constraints package defines a set of constraints for all of the numerical, and comparable types in the language. For example, consider the golang.org/x/exp/constraints#Signed constraint, signed.doc. This constraint requires that the type be any of the signed integer types, `+/-` defined in the Go language, such `int` and `int64`, and any types based on those types. The golang.org/x/exp/constraints#Integer constraint, integer.doc, requires the type to be based on **any** integer type, signed or unsigned, such as `int`, `int64`, `uint`, `uint64`, etc. ### The Ordered Constraint One of the most useful constraints defined in the golang.org/x/exp/constraints package is the golang.org/x/exp/constraints#Ordered constraint, ordered.doc. This constraint list all of the comparable types in the language, and any types based on those types. The golang.org/x/exp/constraints#Ordered constraint covers all numerical types and strings. The golang.org/x/exp/constraints#Ordered constraint is perfect for map keys because all of the types defined in the constraint are comparable. In pkg.def, the `Keys` function has been updated to use the golang.org/x/exp/constraints#Ordered constraint. We can now use the `Keys` function with a map using a key type of `string`, or any other type that is comparable. ## Type Assertions When using constraints that are based on types, and not on methods like interfaces, type assertions are not allowed. For example, in assertions/broken/keys.doc, the `Keys` functions tries to print each map key out to the console, but only if it implements the fmt#Stringer interface. With method based interfaces this is possible, but with constraints we can't make this sort of assertion, assertions/broken.test. As mentioned previously, at compile time, generic function calls are replaced with their concrete types instead. The result is a `Keys` function that takes a map of `string` to `int` and returns a `[]string`, assertions/static.doc. When looking at the compilation error for "concrete" representation of the `Keys` function the error is a little more clear. In Go type assertions, such as those in assertions/static.doc, against concrete types is not allowed. This is no reason to assert if `string` or `User` or another types implements the interface, because the compiler already if it can be done. ## Mixing Method and Type Constraints When defining constraints we have to choose between type based constraints and method based constraints. For example, in mixed, we can can't define a constraint that is either golang.org/x/exp/constraints#Ordered or fmt#Stringer. ## Generic Types In addition to functions, types can also be generic. If we consider building a data store we might define a generic type to represent a "model". In store.model.doc we define a `Model` interface that defines a constraint that all implementations of the `Model` interface must satisfy. The `Model` interface has a type constraint, `[T constraints.Ordered]`. This constraint is now available for use on the interface's methods. Now, in order to implement the `Model` interface, in store.model.doc, a type needs a `ID()` method that returns a type listed in the golang.org/x/exp/constraints#Ordered constraint. In store.store.doc we define a `Store` struct type that has two type constraints, `[K constraints.Ordered]` and `[M Model[K]]`. In this example we are using the `K` constraint defined on the `Store` type to define the constraint on the `Model` type. When defining methods on types that use generics, the receiver of the method needs to be instantiated with the appropriate concrete type or types. Consider the `Find` method on the `Store` type in store.find.doc. The receiver, `(s Store[K, M])`, is instantiated with the concrete types that the `Store` type was instantiated with. Those types can also be used to define arguments and return values for these methods. In store.find.test, we initialize a new `Store` type with the constraints of `string` and `User`. In the tests we are able to work with the original concrete types, instead of interfaces backed by unknown types. --- # Summary In this we covered the basics of generics in Go. We learned how to define constraints, how to use constraints on types, and how to use constraints on methods. Generics is still new to Go, but it is a powerful tool that can be used to make your code more expressive and maintainable.
